author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Turns on R.F.K. Jr. Amid Concerns He Could Attract Republican Voters
description: The former president called Robert F. Kennedy Jr. a ‘Democrat plant’ and attacked his running mate, Nicole Shanahan, who gave $2 million to the Kennedy campaign.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump is sharpening his attacks on the independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr., as new polls show an overlap between their core supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘The Interview,’ a ‘Full-Course Dinner’ With the World’s Most Interesting People
description: The New York Times’s newest podcast, hosted by David Marchese and Lulu Garcia-Navarro, offers wide-ranging conversations with notable guests.
content: For years, David Marchese’s Talk column was one of the most popular features in The New York Times Magazine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eilene Zimmerman
title: Women Artists Are Catching Up, but Equality Will Still Take a While
description: An exhibit at the National Museum of Women in the Arts features an array of artists sharing their views of an increasingly complex world.
content: Late one night a few years ago, the multidisciplinary artist Amanda Phingbodhipakkiya was finishing up a sprawling public installation she had created in Manhattan’s Chelsea neighborhood. A couple walked by, she recalled, and, clearly impressed, remarked to Phingbodhipakkiya: “We love this. Please tell the artist his work is amazing. You must feel so lucky just to get to clean this space.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Kelly
title: Widowed Before 40 and Coping With the Financial Consequences
description: People who suddenly lose a spouse while young can feel unprepared for what their future looks like.
content: It was April 10, 2018, and Colin Brougham hadn’t sent his usual text to his wife that he was biking home. Instead, he lay dead a few blocks away after a commuter train struck him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aubrey Nolan
title: If My Favorite Bookstores Were People
description: An illustrator in New York City imagines the personalities of some local bookshops and how they might be embodied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The Comfortable Problem of Mid TV
description: It’s got a great cast. It looks cinematic. It’s, um … fine. And it’s everywhere.
content: A few years ago, “Atlanta” and “PEN15” were teaching TV new tricks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Vora
title: Children and Museums: You Can’t Start Early Enough
description: Many museums around the country have had children’s programs for years — but they are on the rise now more than ever.
content: Children’s museums might seem like a relatively new phenomenon. But they’ve actually been around since 1899, when the Brooklyn Children’s Museum debuted. It’s still open and still popular.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: After Israel Aid Vote, Pocan Seeks to Show Biden Liberal Dismay on Gaza
description: The progressive Democrat from a rural, mostly white Wisconsin district is highlighting that it is not just young people of color who are concerned about the war.
content: During a town hall-style meeting a short drive from her home in rural southwestern Wisconsin, Elizabeth Humphries asked her congressman how a 66-year-old woman like her could get the message to President Biden that she and her peers are deeply dissatisfied with his administration’s approach to Israel’s war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: 5 Exercises for a Better Sex Life
description: Any physical activity can improve your sexual health. But a few exercises are especially beneficial.
content: As far as your muscles are concerned, sex is just another workout. And like most workouts, the more conditioned you are, the more enjoyable it can be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Raja Abdulrahim, Adam Rasgon and Troy Closson
title: Aid Flows to Gaza Are Rising, U.N. Says, but More Is Needed
description: Israel says the number of trucks entering the enclave has doubled to an average of 400 a day. The U.N. disputes that, but agrees that the pace of deliveries has quickened.
content: Under intense international scrutiny, Israel has expedited the flow of aid into Gaza this month, but humanitarian groups say that more is needed as severe hunger grips the enclave, particularly in the devastated north.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Russia Bombs Power Plants and Ukraine Targets Refineries in Dueling Attacks
description: As missiles caused extensive damage to Ukraine’s power grid, Kyiv continued drone assaults inside Russia that have drawn criticism from Washington.
content: As Russian missiles streaked through the skies above Ukraine before dawn on Saturday, once again targeting the nation’s already battered energy grid in a broad and complex bombardment, Ukrainian drones were flying in the other direction, taking aim at vital oil and gas refineries and other targets inside Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Kate Medley
title: Showcase for Antebellum Homes Displays Their Finery. But What About the History?
description: Each spring, Columbus, Miss., has opened its Civil War-era homes to visitors. Some say the event should reflect more the oppression behind the architecture, and how the city has changed since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: What Would Jesus Do? Tackle the Housing Crisis, Say Some Congregations.
description: The “Yes in God’s Backyard” movement to build affordable housing on faith organizations’ properties is gaining steam in California and elsewhere.
content: Walking past empty pews and stained-glass windows, the Rev. Victor Cyrus-Franklin, pastor of Inglewood First United Methodist Church in Inglewood, Calif., talked about how housing prices were threatening his flock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Human Spectacle
description: What’s it like when all eyes are on you?
content: Gladiators in the Colosseum. Sideshow performers. Reality television. Throughout our history, we’ve loved to gawk at the misery and majesty of others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: The Fashion Influencers of the French Revolution
description: “Liberty Equality Fashion” explores radical shifts in fashion that embodied the ideas of the French Revolution and the women who led the charge.
content: Most days, Anne Higonnet is able to keep her cool. She’s a distinguished professor of art history at Barnard College and Columbia University. Her research has been supported by the Guggenheim and Harvard Radcliffe Institute fellowships. She chooses her words, her tone and her clothing carefully. One day in 2017, though, as Higonnet was quietly working at the Morgan Library & Museum, decorum flew out the windows. She did something slightly unscholarly: She yelped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: Donald Trump Has Never Sounded Like This
description: No major American presidential candidate has talked like he now does at his rallies — not Richard Nixon, not George Wallace, not even Donald Trump himself.
content: It was Super Tuesday at Mar-a-Lago, and the people — his people — were feeling good. They had arrived around sundown, disgorged from a small fleet of buses and ushered into the grand ballroom. Some of them were old hands at this place, they explained with great pleasure. Others, first-timers, gawked visibly at the chandeliers the size of jet turbines, the gilded molding and the grape-dangling cherubs, all that marble and mirror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Alan Blinder and Neelam Bohra
title: ‘Decisions Under Fire’: Campuses Try a Mix of Tactics as Protests Grow
description: Some colleges that initiated police crackdowns on pro-Palestinian protests have since taken a different tack. Others have defended the move. Hundreds have been arrested.
content: Wearing riot helmets and carrying zip ties, Boston police officers moved in one day this week and surrounded a group of pro-Palestinian protesters on a grassy patch of Northeastern University’s campus. Six police wagons were idling nearby, and an officer had issued a terse warning. Mass arrests looked imminent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernhard Warner
title: Daniel Ek’s Next Act: Full-Body Scans for the People
description: The Spotify chief has co-founded a new start-up, Neko Health, that aims to make head-to-toe health scans part of the annual health checkup routine.
content: In conversations with colleagues, fellow entrepreneurs and even musicians over the past decade, Daniel Ek would often abruptly shift the subject to something that really bugged him: health care. “I was like adamant to fix it,” Mr. Ek, the Spotify chief, told DealBook. He saw the industry as a bloated and inefficient colossus in need of disrupting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 6 Podcasts to Soothe an Anxious Mind
description: At a time of unsettling news at home and abroad, these shows offer tips and first-person accounts to alleviate a spiraling sense of unease.
content: There’s no shortage of reasons to feel anxious at the moment — a relentless barrage of devastating news from across the globe, soaring food and housing prices, and an impending presidential election in a polarized nation. But for people who live with an anxiety disorder, spiraling and uncontrollable worries can be constant, regardless of whether there’s any obvious external reason for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: Arlene Shechet’s ‘Girl Group’ Nudges Heavy Metal Men at Storm King
description: Once known for ceramics, she now commands the rolling hills at the prestigious New York sculpture park with a chorus of six giant welded works.
content: The recent late-life critical embrace of a generation of underappreciated major female artists — the 91-year-old nude self-portraitist Joan Semmel, the 84-year-old visual artist and sculptor Barbara Chase-Riboud, the 87-year-old performance and multimedia provocateur Joan Jonas and the Cuban-born abstractionist Carmen Herrera, who died two years ago at age 106 — has brought a measure of satisfaction to the sculptor Arlene Shechet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Deep Beneath London, Onetime Bomb Shelters Will Become a Tourist Attraction
description: Used for spying, a phone exchange and more over the years, a semi-secret web of tunnels in central London could open to the public in 2027.
content: There’s a locked door on the eastbound platform of the Chancery Lane station of the London Underground. The door is unassuming, sturdy and white.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: The Hardest Letter to the Editor
description: During President Bill Clinton’s impeachment, a reader sent the letters desk a brick inscribed with a message. No damage was reported.
content: The message was strong: “CONVICT CRIMINAL CLINTON.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Suddenly, Chinese Spies Seem to Be Popping Up All Over Europe
description: A flurry of arrests this week reflect the continent’s newly toughened response to Beijing’s espionage activities and political meddling.
content: One of the men, a young Briton known for his hawkish views on China, worked as an aide to a prominent member of the British Parliament. Another, a German citizen of Chinese descent, was an assistant to a member of the European Parliament representing Germany’s far right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Wendy Dorr, Sonia Herrero and Melissa Kirsch
title: ‘Challengers’ Is Sexy … but Is It Good Tennis?
description: A sports journalist on what the film got right and wrong.
content: On Friday, Luca Guadagnino’s “Challengers” was released in theaters across the United States and Canada. The film follows three tennis players who, over the course of several years, compete against one another and become entangled in an ever-shifting love triangle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martine Thompson
title: How to Keep Your Friendships Intact While Wedding Planning
description: The soon-to-be-married couple and their closest friends might experience stress and even tension leading up to their nuptials. Here’s how to avoid a friendship breakup.
content: Weddings have a way of bringing pre-existing issues with friends or family members to the surface. Take a peek in any wedding nook of TikTok or Instagram, and you are likely to encounter horror stories of wedding party members experiencing “the maid of honor curse” or watching a friend turn into a “bridezilla” or “groomzilla” during the planning process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Harvey Weinstein and the Limits of ‘She Said, She Said, She Said’
description: A chorus of voices is what made #MeToo so powerful. Why did it backfire in court?
content: I often wake up these days feeling as though I’m living in an upside-down world. Thursday was one such morning: Just as Donald Trump prepared to spend another day in a Manhattan criminal court to face charges related to hush money paid to a porn star he allegedly had sex with, in the same spot where Harvey Weinstein was convicted of rape four years ago, Mr. Weinstein’s New York conviction was overturned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Hamas Says It Is Reviewing Israeli Proposal on Cease-Fire Deal
description: The statement came as anticipation was growing of an Israeli invasion of Rafah, where more than a million Gazans have been displaced.
content: Hamas said on Saturday that it was reviewing a new Israeli proposal for a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, a move that comes amid efforts to break a deadlock in the talks between the armed group and Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: Putin’s War Will Soon Reach Russians’ Tax Bills
description: Russia’s president has signaled an increase in income and corporate taxes that will help finance the war. The move reflects his firm control over Russian policy.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appears on track to institute a rare tax increase on corporations and high earners, a move that reflects both the burgeoning costs of his war in Ukraine and the firm control he has over the Russian elite as he embarks on a fifth term in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts, Matthew Eadie and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Crackdowns at 4 College Protests Lead to More Than 200 Arrests
description: The police made arrests at Washington University in St. Louis, Northeastern in Boston, Arizona State and Indiana, as more schools move in on encampments.
content: More than 200 protesters were arrested on Saturday at Northeastern University, Arizona State University, Indiana University and Washington University in St. Louis, according to officials, as colleges across the country struggle to quell growing pro-Palestinian demonstrations and encampments on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alina Tugend
title: Upgraded Museums Add New Value to College Campuses
description: Educational institutions across the United States are spending more money to renovate museums and make them a more integral part of learning.
content: Michigan State University and Yale University are very different types of higher education institutions, but they have at least one thing in common: They have been spending millions of dollars to revamp their museums.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Trump’s Remarks in the Hush Money Trial
description: Each day before and after court proceedings, the former president stepped out in front of the cameras and offered his version of the case.
content: Donald J. Trump spent the bulk of the past week in a Manhattan courtroom, standing trial as the first American president to face criminal prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom and Hurubie Meko
title: How a New Trial for Harvey Weinstein Could Again Test the Legal System
description: A new jury would hear from only one or both of the women whom he was convicted of assaulting, in what analysts say will be a much narrower and weaker case.
content: As one of Harvey Weinstein’s key accusers took the witness stand during his trial in New York, she broke down in tears, sobbing uncontrollably. After a brief break, she still could not compose herself. The trial was adjourned for the day. Hyperventilating, the woman was ushered out and her piercing screams bellowed out from a back room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 321
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken to Meet With Arab Officials in Saudi Arabia About Israel-Gaza War
description: The U.S. secretary of state plans to raise the issues of hostages held by Hamas, a potential cease-fire, humanitarian aid and a long-term political solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will travel to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Sunday to speak with top Arab officials and try to figure out possible solutions for the thorniest issues of the Israel-Gaza war, including humanitarian aid, reconstruction and hostages, the State Department said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Saving Time
description: The advice to live each day to its fullest can seem like a cliché, but figuring out how to actually do that can be pretty challenging.
content: Any advice I’ve ever been given that’s actually resonated has boiled down to a variation on the same basic theme: Life is short. Stop wasting it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Left and Right on the Happiness Scale
description: Readers largely take issue with a column by Ross Douthat about the left’s supposed unhappiness.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Memoirs by Poets
description: Carl Sandburg’s boyhood; Carolyn Forché’s political awakening.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Colin Jost and Scarlett Johansson Lead ‘D.C.-Palooza’
description: In Washington, celebrities mixed with journalists and government officials at glittery parties before the annual White House Correspondents’ Association dinner.
content: The early arrivals at a party thrown by the Hollywood powerhouse Creative Artists Agency on Friday night seemed to be weighing the same question: Just how much could they expect to let loose during this year’s White House Correspondents’ Association Dinner weekend?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld
title: At Trump’s Trial, a Window Into the Golden Era of Tabloids
description: The testimony of David Pecker, the former publisher of The National Enquirer, included stories of celebrity encounters and his own wild journalistic tactics.
content: Inside a staid Manhattan courtroom this week, flashes from a bygone era appeared, recollections of a celebrity-studded world of leveraged secrets and traded favors, and one in which publications sold at supermarket checkout counters wielded real cultural and political power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: In Race to Build A.I., Tech Plans a Big Plumbing Upgrade
description: The spending that the industry’s giants expect artificial intelligence to require is starting to come into focus — and it is jarringly large.
content: If 2023 was the tech industry’s year of the A.I. chatbot, 2024 is turning out to be the year of A.I. plumbing. It may not sound as exciting, but tens of billions of dollars are quickly being spent on behind-the-scenes technology for the industry’s A.I. boom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Wayne
title: Exploring Pittsburgh’s Legacy of Steel
description: At the Carnegie Museum of Art, an installation by the artist Marie Watt celebrates the region’s industrial history with I-beams and glass.
content: If there is one word that defines Pittsburgh, it is steel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Fisher
title: A Tale of Young Flames, and Their Dark Futures, After a Coup
description: In Lily Meyer’s first novel, “Short War,” love and family ties are tested by a nation’s upheaval.
content: The translator and critic Lily Meyer’s first novel opens in Santiago, Chile, with a lovely, eerie assuredness, a moment like an incantation: a girl walking toward a boy through a crowded party, illuminated. “He knew, with inexplicable, terrifying certainty, that she was coming for him,” the boy, Gabriel Lazris, thinks. He refers to this later as “the true start of his life,” the night he met Caro Ravest, in 1973.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: G.O.P. Asks Secret Service to Move Protesters Away From Convention Venue
description: The Republican National Committee said moving protesters farther away from the venue in Milwaukee would reduce the risk of confrontations.
content: The Republican Party sent a letter to the Secret Service on Friday urging the police agency to keep protesters farther away from the venue for the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee in July.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: What Is a ‘Decent Wage’? France’s Michelin Ignites a Debate.
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 27, 2024.
content: “If workers are just in survival mode, it’s a big problem.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner, Judson Jones and Yan Zhuang
title: At Least 5 Dead in Oklahoma and Iowa as Nighttime Tornadoes Strike
description: An infant was among those killed, officials said. Parts of five states — Arkansas, Louisiana, Oklahoma, Missouri and Texas — were under a tornado watch on Sunday.
content: Severe thunderstorms and high winds over the weekend left at least five people dead in Oklahoma and Iowa, including an infant, as a series of tornadoes ripped through the Great Plains, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley and Annie Flanagan
title: New Orleans Likes to Drink. They Spotted a Huge Recycling Opportunity
description: College students started a venture that has diverted glass bottles from landfills and crushed them into sand for coastal restoration efforts.
content: It started with a lament over the fate of empty beer and wine bottles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: Yair Lapid Says the World Misunderstands Israel
description: Frustrated at the growing protest movement, the opposition leader defends his country’s “existential” war.
content: This is the debut of The Interview, The New York Times’s new weekly series, featuring in-depth conversations with fascinating people. Each week, David Marchese or Lulu Garcia-Navarro will speak with notable figures in the worlds of culture, politics, business, sports, wellness and beyond. Like the magazine’s former Talk column, the conversations will appear online and in print, but now you can also listen to them in our new weekly podcast, “The Interview,” which is available wherever you get your podcasts. Below, you’ll find Lulu’s first interview with the Israeli opposition leader Yair Lapid; David’s first interview, with the actress Anne Hathaway, is here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 27, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 27, 2024.
content: An article on Thursday about a prosecutor’s argument that the men accused of plotting the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, could be held past a war crimes sentence misstated the legal disposition of detainees at Guantánamo Bay. Of the 30 people held there, 11 have been charged or convicted, not tried or convicted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What Students Read Before They Protest
description: How Israel became the focus of so much of contemporary protest politics.
content: When I was a college undergraduate 25 years ago, the fancy school that I attended offered what it styled as a “core curriculum” that was really nothing of the sort. Instead of giving students a set of foundational courses and assignments, a shared base of important ideas and arguments, our core assembled a grab bag of courses from different disciplines and invited us to pick among them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Regulators Seize Republic First, a Troubled Philadelphia Bank
description: The relatively small bank, the first to fail this year, will have its deposits assumed by another Pennsylvania lender, Fulton Bank.
content: Regulators late Friday seized Republic First Bancorp, a troubled Philadelphia lender, in the first U.S. bank failure this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Barnard Ends Suspensions for Most Student Protesters Who Were Arrested
description: The students had been among more than 100 who were suspended for participating in an encampment at Columbia University.
content: Barnard College will allow most of the 53 students who were arrested and suspended after participating in a pro-Palestinian protest encampment at Columbia University to return to its campus, administrators said in a statement on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Nyimas Laula
title: From a Heavy Metal Band in Hijabs, a Message of Girl Power
description: Voice of Baceprot has electrified audiences and built a large following in Indonesia. Now the group is taking its music to the West.
content: The drummer crashed her cymbals. The bass player clawed at her guitar. The crowd raised index and pinkie fingers in approval. The lead singer and guitarist stepped up to the mic and screamed: “Our body is not public property!” And dozens of fans threw themselves into a frenzy for the hijab-wearing heavy metal trio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Anne Hathaway Is Done Trying to Please
description: On the debut of ‘The Interview,' the actress talks to David Marchese about learning to let go of other people’s opinions.
content: This is the debut of The Interview, The New York Times’s new weekly series, featuring in-depth conversations with fascinating people. Each week, David Marchese or Lulu Garcia-Navarro will speak with notable figures in the worlds of culture, politics, business, sports, wellness and beyond. Like the Magazine’s former Talk column, the conversations will appear online and in print, but now you can also listen to them in our new weekly podcast, “The Interview,” which is available wherever you get your podcasts. Below, you’ll find David’s first interview with the actress Anne Hathaway; Lulu’s first interview, with the Israeli opposition leader Yair Lapid, is here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Delta Air Lines Flight Loses Emergency Slide After Takeoff, Officials Say
description: The plane had taken off from Kennedy International Airport when crew members noticed problems near its right wing, Delta said. What became of the slide is unknown.
content: A Boeing 767 plane flown by Delta Air Lines lost an emergency slide on Friday, prompting it to return to New York not long after taking off, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Climber Is Killed in Fall at Denali National Park
description: Climbers were navigating rock, snow and ice on Mount Johnson when they fell about 1,000 feet, killing one and injuring another, the National Park Service said.
content: One climber died and another was seriously injured after they fell about 1,000 feet from a peak at Denali National Park and Preserve in Alaska late on Thursday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Minho Kim and Zach Montague
title: ‘I’m a Grown Man Running Against a 6-Year-Old’: Biden Lets Trump Jokes Fly at Annual Roast
description: Journalists and politicians schmoozed over filet mignon at the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner as pro-Palestinian protesters gathered outside.
content: President Biden didn’t waste time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,043
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Biden Administration Restores Health Protections for Gay and Transgender People
description: The Health and Human Services Department finalized a rule prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, reversing a Trump-era policy.
content: The Biden administration announced expansive new protections on Friday for gay and transgender medical patients, prohibiting federally funded health providers and insurers from discriminating on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danyel Smith
title: These 5 Black Ballerinas Blazed Their Own Trail
description: The birth of a pioneering Black dance company comes alive in Karen Valby’s “The Swans of Harlem.”
content: The sense of loss in “The Swans of Harlem: Five Black Ballerinas, Fifty Years of Sisterhood, and Their Reclamation of a Groundbreaking History” is strong. No matter how painstaking the detail or how sparkly its jubilee energy, these women — Lydia Abarca, Gayle McKinney-Griffith, Sheila Rohan, Marcia Sells and Karlya Shelton — were robbed of laurels upon which they might now be resting. Abarca’s family was so concerned by her erasure from dance history (and her apparent attendant depression) that they instigated the telling of this story. If it were just a quest for cultural redress, the result might have been a dusty scroll of the Swans’ ballet bona fides. It’s by getting personal that it leaps high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Justice Alito Is Holding Trump to a Different Standard
description: On what planet were Trump’s actions a normal response to political defeat?
content: I mentioned it in passing in my Friday column, but I was struck — disturbed, really — by one specific point made by Justice Samuel Alito during Thursday’s oral arguments in Trump v. United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: A Match Made in MAGA: How a Friendship Helped J.D. Vance Land on Trump’s V.P. List
description: The Ohio senator and Donald Trump Jr. have bonded politically and personally. It’s a relationship that could factor into the former president’s search for a running mate.
content: It was just 43 days before the 2022 Republican primary in Ohio, and former President Donald J. Trump had yet to throw his weight behind a Senate candidate. J.D. Vance, a political novice competing in a packed field, had a huge problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: The Sounds of Music
description: Mike Ellison’s debut puzzle brings music back into the house — lots of it!
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: Nobody Saw Andy Kim Coming. That’s What He Was Counting On.
description: Mr. Kim, the New Jersey congressman, has become the odds-on favorite to win Robert Menendez’s Senate seat. His strategy? Don’t ask anyone for permission.
content: Facing federal charges that he accepted bribes, including cash, gold bars and a Mercedes-Benz, Senator Robert Menendez announced on Friday, Sept. 22, that he would not resign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hanc
title: Museums Are Changing How They Bring Natural Sciences to Life
description: The Cleveland Museum of Natural History is rolling out two new exhibition halls and making its scientists more accessible. And don’t forget the dinosaurs.
content: Guiding a visitor along the 22-foot-high, 406-foot-long curtain of glass fronting the Cleveland Museum of Natural History’s new exhibit hall, Caitlin Colleary spots a familiar face — one from which three large horns are protruding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How Louis Cato, Bandleader for ‘The Late Show,’ Spends His Sundays
description: Before Mr. Cato gets ready for his week with Stephen Colbert, he’s playing games with his daughter, hiding in hoodies and making music of his own.
content: Before Louis Cato took over for his friend Jon Batiste as bandleader of “The Late Show with Stephen Colbert” in 2022, he put out records that swerved from funk to jazz to blues and soul, with some R&B and Latin influences along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My Landlord Says I Can’t Sublet My Apartment. What if I Do Anyway?
description: Rent-stabilized tenants can request to sublet their apartments in most cases, and landlords cannot unreasonably withhold consent. But what is ‘reasonable?’
content: Q: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in Brooklyn, and my lease is up for renewal. I plan to attend school outside the city and need to sublet my unit. But my lease contains a provision stating that “any form of subletting or assignment of my lease in this affordable housing program is strictly prohibited and unlawful.” My landlord has said that because of this clause (part of an “Attachment N-1: Pre-Lease Acknowledgment and Certification”), I don’t have the right to assign the lease to someone else or to sublet my unit. Is my landlord allowed to make this rule? What steps, if any, can I take to keep this apartment that I love?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Max Thieriot Likes to Watch Things Grow, Including Himself
description: The “Fire Country” star talks about the road trips, the farm equipment and the family time that keep him grounded.
content: For Max Thieriot, one of the creators and the star of the CBS series “Fire Country,” all roads lead back to his roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Alberta Draws Academia Into Its Fight With Justin Trudeau
description: Alberta is seeking powers to veto funding agreements between the federal government and provincial entities, including postsecondary institutions.
content: Federal funding promises can shape how much, or how fast, provinces advance their own agenda items, and Alberta wants Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to know that his to-do list will have to wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner and Ravi Mattu
title: Beyond Pulling Donations
description: Business executives who are concerned about antisemitism on college campuses have other options for influencing the schools’ actions, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes.
content: Many business leaders have told me they are deeply concerned about incidents of harassment against Jewish students that have taken place at and around universities like Columbia and appear to be increasing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic
title: A City Scarred by Terrorism Prepares an Olympic Opening Without Walls
description: The opening ceremony for this summer’s Paris Games will be held outside a stadium — an Olympics first. Making it safe is complicated.
content: A terrorist attack of 2015 that left her city angry and heartbroken persuaded Paris’s mayor, Anne Hidalgo, to campaign for the Olympic Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Your New Chocolate Chip Cookie Recipe
description: Leave it to Rick Martínez to take everyone’s favorite cookie and make it even better with butterscotch-y, brown-buttery piloncillo.
content: I have never met Rick Martínez — I would love to, ideally with Choco in tow — but I consider him my cookie godfather. In 2017 he wrote about his favorite brown butter chocolate chip cookies for Bon Appétit; I made them and won third place in New York magazine’s staff holiday cookie contest that year. I’ve made the cookies a million times since, to the point that friends refer to them as “those cookies.” Rick does a lot of things well (like grilled chicken and brown butter glazed radishes and refried beans), but damn if that man doesn’t know a chocolate chip cookie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Best Red Carpet Looks at the White House Correspondents’ Association Dinner
description: Scarlett Johansson, Colin Jost and Senator John Fetterman made their entrances at the annual journalism celebration in Washington.
content: It hasn’t been the “nerd prom” for a while. Once a popular target of jokes about bad fashion (and not just from the evening’s featured comedian host), the White House Correspondents’ Association Dinner has morphed in recent years into a less campy, more staid prelude to the Met Gala, which takes place days later. It’s only fitting, really, given the subtext of journalists being jailed around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich, Maggie Haberman and William K. Rashbaum
title: Echoing Their Client, Trump’s Lawyers Pursue an Absolutist Defense
description: Donald J. Trump demands praise and concedes no faults, denying his lawyers time-honored defense tactics.
content: Donald J. Trump is a thrice-married man accused of covering up a sex scandal with a porn star after the world heard him brag about grabbing women by their genitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Marked Up
description: Rich Norris’s puzzle guards its treasures.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Rich Norris was a major New York Times Crossword constructor from 1994 to 2008, contributing 186 grids and 118 Saturday puzzles. He also edited the L.A. Times Crossword from 1999 to 2022 and helped develop other crossword syndicates and online communities, which might explain his absence from our pages. Last year, he won the MEmoRiaL Award at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament (named for Merl Reagle, another prolific puzzle maker), and he returned to the Times Crossword with a Friday grid in March 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benji Backer
title: I’m a Young Conservative, and I Want My Party to Lead the Fight Against Climate Change
description: Instead of continuing the environmental legacy they were once known for, Republicans have ceded the fight against climate change to Democrats.
content: Conservatives were once America’s environmental champions. Not that long ago, Republican presidents were carrying out the Clean Air and Water Acts, creating the Environmental Protection Agency, expanding the National Park System and even initiating the country’s most authoritative report on climate change, the National Climate Assessment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Jon Bon Jovi Hits the Town, and Gustavo Dudamel Takes the Stage
description: This week, fans turned out for a new documentary about Jon Bon Jovi and took in a performance led by Gustavo Dudamel at the New York Philharmonic’s spring gala.
content: Out & About is a column that covers the events where notable, powerful and influential figures gather — and their outfits. This week: We attended a screening of “Thank You, Goodnight: The Bon Jovi Story” and the New York Philharmonic’s spring gala.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Andrew Davis, 80, Dies; Renowned Conductor Who Championed Britain’s Music
description: Celebrated for his long tenure with Lyric Opera of Chicago, he led this and other orchestras with force and a notably energetic podium presence.
content: Andrew Davis, an ebullient British conductor who brought energy to his countrymen’s compositions and passion to hundreds of opera performances, died on April 20 in Chicago. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Kantor
title: The Offense That Harvey Weinstein Can Never Be Convicted Of
description: The movie producer won his appeal in New York on Thursday. But his story, at its core, is about work, and it can’t be measured by a criminal court.
content: For the first time in years, there is a chance that Harvey Weinstein could walk free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bilal Shbair and Hiba Yazbek
title: Heat Wave Strains Pharmacist’s Ability to Get Crucial Medicine to Gazans
description: High temperatures this week have left people sweltering and challenged businesses that need to keep their products cool.
content: A heat wave in the Gaza Strip this week, with temperatures soaring above 100 degrees Fahrenheit the past few days, has not only made life intolerable for the hundreds of thousands of displaced people trying to rebuild their lives in tent cities but has made it hard for some businesses to operate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura van Straaten
title: After Setbacks, a Textile Artist Finds New Success
description: Venues across the U.S. and beyond are giving Liz Collins, who first found fame as a fashion designer, the art-world recognition that had eluded her.
content: During an art residency last year in a former castle in the Umbrian countryside, the textile artist Liz Collins sat in her temporary studio stitching a needlepoint. She was surrounded by long bulletin boards, on which she had tacked dozens of her gem-colored watercolor works and ink drawings, along with images of shapes that inspire her. On her worktable lay swatches of the silk and Lurex she would soon use to render her paintings and drawings into textiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Upshot Staff
title: 10 Years, 100 Stories: The Work That Defines the Upshot
description: The Upshot is 10 years old this week. Here’s a collection of our most distinctive work from the last decade.
content: The Upshot is 10 years old this week. Here’s a collection of our most distinctive work from the last decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof and Taylor Maggiacomo
title: Why Does the U.S. Arm Ukraine With Fanfare and Israel in Secret?
description: The Biden administration should be more transparent about weapons sent to Israel.
content: The Biden administration should be more transparent about weapons sent to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Shao, Mika Gröndahl, Anjali Singhvi and Marco Hernandez
title: How the U.S. Humanitarian Pier in Gaza Will Work
description: A pier operation being assembled by U.S. service members will involve an elaborate process to provide Gazans with just a portion of the aid they need.
content: A pier operation being assembled by U.S. service members will involve an elaborate process to provide Gazans with just a portion of the aid they need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Pappas, Caroline Kim, Gabriel Blanco and Noah Throop
title: Why Donald Trump Feels Betrayed by Corporate America
description: Donald J. Trump’s relationship with Wall Street has changed dramatically since 2016. He was closely aligned with business leaders during his first term in office, until a series of events exposed their divisions.
content: Donald J. Trump’s relationship with Wall Street has changed dramatically since 2016. He was closely aligned with business leaders during his first term in office, until a series of events exposed their divisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Rebecca Suner and Gabriel Blanco
title: What We Learned From the First Witnesses
description: The first week of testimony has ended in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.
content: The first week of testimony has ended in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.
source.name: The New York Times
